body: What about lying, divorce, adultery, fornication, lusting, usury, judging, idolatry, etc? What about every single time you act in your own interest knowing it will cost someone else, even just a little bit? What about every tiny bit of doubt or anger at God? Surely you cannot claim you never do any of that, and if you do you are a liar. I do not think "blasphemy of the holy spirit" is referring to sucking dicks, something mentioned less than 10 times in the entire Protestant canon, and spuriously at that. No, you are the one perverting the gospel. You brag about your superiority because you see a speck in your brother's eye, even though you have a log in your own eye. You hypocrite! First remove the log from your own eye, and then you will see clearly to remove the speck in your brother's eye.

post.body:
>Hwang is a trustee of the Fuller Theology Seminary, and co-founder of the Grace and Mercy Foundation, whose mission is to serve the poor and oppressed. The foundation had assets approaching $500 million at the end of 2018, according to its latest filing.

>“It’s not all about the money, you know,” he said in a rare interview with a Fuller Institute executive in 2018, in which he spoke about his calling as an investor and his Christian faith. “It’s about the long term, and God certainly has a long-term view.”

More on Fuller Theological seminary: 

>While Fuller has established policies, the seminary is open to difference in opinion among students and faculty.[17] The seminary's current president, Mark Labberton, marched in favor of comprehensive immigration reform and a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants in 2013.[18] Others have expressed support in the Fuller forum for the Black Lives Matter movement as raising awareness for civil rights.[19] In 2015, some faculty at the seminary called on Christians to openly discuss, with respect, issues related to race, gender, sexual orientation, refugees, and immigrants.[20] While the seminary officially recognizes marriage as "between a man and a woman", the seminary did allow an LGBTQ student club to organize on campus; the club, "OneTable", became the first LGBTQ group organized within an evangelical seminary.[21]
post.body_html:
Hwang is a trustee of the Fuller Theology Seminary, and co-founder of the Grace and Mercy Foundation, whose mission is to serve the poor and oppressed. The foundation had assets approaching $500 million at the end of 2018, according to its latest filing.

“It’s not all about the money, you know,” he said in a rare interview with a Fuller Institute executive in 2018, in which he spoke about his calling as an investor and his Christian faith. “It’s about the long term, and God certainly has a long-term view.”

More on Fuller Theological seminary:

While Fuller has established policies, the seminary is open to difference in opinion among students and faculty.[17] The seminary's current president, Mark Labberton, marched in favor of comprehensive immigration reform and a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants in 2013.[18] Others have expressed support in the Fuller forum for the Black Lives Matter movement as raising awareness for civil rights.[19] In 2015, some faculty at the seminary called on Christians to openly discuss, with respect, issues related to race, gender, sexual orientation, refugees, and immigrants.[20] While the seminary officially recognizes marriage as "between a man and a woman", the seminary did allow an LGBTQ student club to organize on campus; the club, "OneTable", became the first LGBTQ group organized within an evangelical seminary.[21]
post.title: One of World’s Greatest Hidden Fortunes Is Wiped Out in Days [God smiting Fuller Theological Seminary?]

body: I think they were confused. The most striking example is how the Genesis writer tries to portray the snake as the good guy in the story, so they either hated God or got God and Satan mixed up. Another thing you have to realize is that much of the bible is forgery, especially in the Old Testament which has had thousands of years to be corrupted, and a common tendency among the counterfeit writings is to miscredit God with something evil that the author supports, such as genocide, sex slavery and animal sacrifice.

post.body:
(2 Samuel 24:1) Again the anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and he incited David against them, saying, “Go and take a census of Israel and Judah.”

(1 Chronicles 21:1) Satan rose up against Israel and incited David to take a census of Israel.

They are both the same story as David takes a census of his people. But who commands David to take a census is obviously very different.

I think (Isaiah 45:6-7) is an interesting depiction of LORD as he describes himself saying:

"That they may know from the rising of the sun, and from the west, that there is none beside me. I am the LORD, and there is none else. I form the light, and create darkness: I make peace, and create evil: I the LORD do all these things."

My question is were the ancient Israelites often deceived or confused about who exactly they worshipped? Or are these passages showing the evolving theology of the ancient Israelites?
post.body_html:
(2 Samuel 24:1) Again the anger of the LORD burned against Israel, and he incited David against them, saying, “Go and take a census of Israel and Judah.”

(1 Chronicles 21:1) Satan rose up against Israel and incited David to take a census of Israel.

They are both the same story as David takes a census of his people. But who commands David to take a census is obviously very different.

I think (Isaiah 45:6-7) is an interesting depiction of LORD as he describes himself saying:

"That they may know from the rising of the sun, and from the west, that there is none beside me. I am the LORD, and there is none else. I form the light, and create darkness: I make peace, and create evil: I the LORD do all these things."

My question is were the ancient Israelites often deceived or confused about who exactly they worshipped? Or are these passages showing the evolving theology of the ancient Israelites?
post.title: Lord and Satan

post.body:
Just spit-balling, but...

I do not think God necessarily anticipated the rejection of Christ until the coming days to His crucifixion.  I'm sure in the back of His mind (If I can personify) He may have believed it would happen based on past events of the Jewish elite constantly rejecting him and confounding His true nature...

So, His failsafe was to open the Kingdom to everyone since His people rejected Him in His pure form and establish the Church.  His 2nd coming would be in the hopes that Israel would repent for a crucified and risen Messiah. (I do not think that the Jews will accept Him even still, especially those Jesus calls "fake Jews")

BUT, if they had accepted him, then I truly believe the reign of a thousand years would have begun then and there.

Anyway, lemme know your thoughts.

body:
> It's beginnings were Henotheistic in its recognition of other gods.

That is not the real beginning. If you recall correctly paganism and idol worship was a constant problem in the old testament. Those very same gods that were so prevalent that historians think they were the original religion: El, Baal, Asherah, etc. are exactly the ones the prophets in the old testament constantly complain about people worshiping. The paganism in the Torah is not a good indicator, because it has been heavily edited by the lying pen of scribes, many of whom were those same pagans.

> But to speak of Noah, Lot, and Abraham, I believe they were visited by a pre-incarnate Christ - Melchizedek and blessed.

But if it was originally only meant for the Jewish people, why would they have been blessed?
body_html:
It's beginnings were Henotheistic in its recognition of other gods.

That is not the real beginning. If you recall correctly paganism and idol worship was a constant problem in the old testament. Those very same gods that were so prevalent that historians think they were the original religion: El, Baal, Asherah, etc. are exactly the ones the prophets in the old testament constantly complain about people worshiping. The paganism in the Torah is not a good indicator, because it has been heavily edited by the lying pen of scribes, many of whom were those same pagans.

But to speak of Noah, Lot, and Abraham, I believe they were visited by a pre-incarnate Christ - Melchizedek and blessed.

But if it was originally only meant for the Jewish people, why would they have been blessed?

Just spit-balling, but...

I do not think God necessarily anticipated the rejection of Christ until the coming days to His crucifixion.  I'm sure in the back of His mind (If I can personify) He may have believed it would happen based on past events of the Jewish elite constantly rejecting him and confounding His true nature...

So, His failsafe was to open the Kingdom to everyone since His people rejected Him in His pure form and establish the Church.  His 2nd coming would be in the hopes that Israel would repent for a crucified and risen Messiah. (I do not think that the Jews will accept Him even still, especially those Jesus calls "fake Jews")

BUT, if they had accepted him, then I truly believe the reign of a thousand years would have begun then and there.

Anyway, lemme know your thoughts.

>Hwang is a trustee of the Fuller Theology Seminary, and co-founder of the Grace and Mercy Foundation, whose mission is to serve the poor and oppressed. The foundation had assets approaching $500 million at the end of 2018, according to its latest filing.

>“It’s not all about the money, you know,” he said in a rare interview with a Fuller Institute executive in 2018, in which he spoke about his calling as an investor and his Christian faith. “It’s about the long term, and God certainly has a long-term view.”

More on Fuller Theological seminary: 

>While Fuller has established policies, the seminary is open to difference in opinion among students and faculty.[17] The seminary's current president, Mark Labberton, marched in favor of comprehensive immigration reform and a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants in 2013.[18] Others have expressed support in the Fuller forum for the Black Lives Matter movement as raising awareness for civil rights.[19] In 2015, some faculty at the seminary called on Christians to openly discuss, with respect, issues related to race, gender, sexual orientation, refugees, and immigrants.[20] While the seminary officially recognizes marriage as "between a man and a woman", the seminary did allow an LGBTQ student club to organize on campus; the club, "OneTable", became the first LGBTQ group organized within an evangelical seminary.[21]
post.body_html:
Hwang is a trustee of the Fuller Theology Seminary, and co-founder of the Grace and Mercy Foundation, whose mission is to serve the poor and oppressed. The foundation had assets approaching $500 million at the end of 2018, according to its latest filing.

“It’s not all about the money, you know,” he said in a rare interview with a Fuller Institute executive in 2018, in which he spoke about his calling as an investor and his Christian faith. “It’s about the long term, and God certainly has a long-term view.”

More on Fuller Theological seminary:

While Fuller has established policies, the seminary is open to difference in opinion among students and faculty.[17] The seminary's current president, Mark Labberton, marched in favor of comprehensive immigration reform and a pathway to citizenship for undocumented immigrants in 2013.[18] Others have expressed support in the Fuller forum for the Black Lives Matter movement as raising awareness for civil rights.[19] In 2015, some faculty at the seminary called on Christians to openly discuss, with respect, issues related to race, gender, sexual orientation, refugees, and immigrants.[20] While the seminary officially recognizes marriage as "between a man and a woman", the seminary did allow an LGBTQ student club to organize on campus; the club, "OneTable", became the first LGBTQ group organized within an evangelical seminary.[21]
post.title: One of World’s Greatest Hidden Fortunes Is Wiped Out in Days [God smiting Fuller Theological Seminary?]

body:
In those days the only old manuscript was Codex Vaticanus, which the Catholic Church heavily guarded and did not want people to see. Occasionally they let a few people see it for a few hours under supervision, and would snatch it away if they stared at a reading for too long. Thus they had to use the much later Byzantine texts as preserved by the Orthodox church. And we also have learned more about early Christianity in the past 50 years than we had in the entire 2000 years until then. Scholars in the 1500s were a new thing, and their knowledge was quite limited and usually heavily biased. On top of that, they faced pressure from the Catholic Church to conform, which is why the Textus Receptus contains passages that only appeared in the Vulgate until then, which they had translated into Greek.

And Biblical Greek and Hebrew are dead dialects and rather difficult in many places. Even today there are heated debates about what certain things mean. In the 15 and 1600s their knowledge was even more limited.

parent.body:
Some of the translations in the NIV were a little too strongly interpretive for my taste. Never any outright mistranslations, but sometimes worded in ways that polluted the meaning/spirit of the text, enough to make me uncomfortable in some instances. This became a little more apparent as I grew, developed a higher understanding, and even just a more advanced reading level. 

I don't discount the NIV, but perhaps just from my own experience, I view it as a "beginner's Bible" for a younger audience. There are plenty of Bible versions that came into existence that would deem as outright wrong (literally Bibles where they introduced cussing and swearing to appeal to prisoners, etc.), and I in no way would ever categorize the NIV into that group, but there is enough discomfort that I personally avoid it when given a choice. I would recommend a few other versions/translations before recommending the NIV.

parent.body:
Sir, if you speak english, the KJV is the word of God. Other translations worded differently than the KJV are not the word of God. Why do I say that? Well, let me show you an example. Consider Matthew 19:9:

Here is what the KJV says:
"And I say unto you, Whosoever shall put away his wife, except it be for **fornication**, and shall marry another, committeth adultery: and whoso marrieth her which is put away doth commit adultery."

Here is what other versions say (NASB for example):
"And I say to you, whoever divorces his wife, except for **sexual immorality**, and marries another woman commits adultery.”

What is fornication? Fornication is sexual union between two unmarried people, neither of which have been married before. We see that the **ONLY** lawful reason given for divorce is fornication. And that can only happen on during the betrothal period. 

What is adultery? Adultery is sexual union with another person who is **not** one's spouse. There is absolutely **NO** permission given to men to divorce for the cause of adultery.

The phrase *sexual immorality* is an umbrella term for both adultery and fornication. And that is a problem, sir. The NASB is telling people to commit adultery! Jesus did not give permission to divorce for the cause of adultery.

"Add thou not unto his words, lest he reprove thee, and thou be found a liar." - Proverbs 30:6

May these words be a blessing to you, friend.

body:
> Westcott and Hort heavily dealt with the occult

Lots of Christians used to be involved in occult antics, more examples being the Salem witch trials and medieval obsession with magic and slaying dragons. It sounds abhorrent today but these things were much more commonplace and tempting back then. In any case as I said they do not make editorial changes, they merely select the extant Greek variant which is most likely to be the original. Usually this is something like the order of a few words.

> Kurt Aland doesn't believe in the canonicity of the Bible

Unless you're Catholic or Orthodox there's no reason for you to either.

> The other is that either Codex Sinaitcus or Vaticanus is a forgery and both are corrupted.

They are corrupt, but the majority text is later and even more corrupt. All NT references in the first few centuries reference pre-Alexandrian texts, nothing Byzantine. Even though some quote Byzantine interpolations such as Mark 16:9-20, that just means that passage was added before the Byzantine text took shape and easily existed in the earlier text type back then.

body:
But the Textus Receptus didn't exist until the 16th century with Erasmus. And the Majority Text is a later branch of the original that became popular in the Eastern Orthodox churches.

And the new translations are anything but liberal scholarship. All of them refuse to select variants that are no longer extant in the rather late Greek manuscripts we have in our possession today. Even when it's painfully obvious that the original was different, an example being 1 Corinthians 14:34-35 not belonging in the text, they will only go with available Greek manuscript variants.

body: It didn't say he justified it, it actually implied that they are *worried* this is going to happen. And I am too, I have lately been seeing conservatives abandon everything they stood for and move towards fascism in reaction to the left. Periods of civil unrest and paranoia can make people feel like an iron fist is the only thing that can save them, and believe me want-to-be dictators will take every advantage of that as they always have in history.
